results.title: Invasion of the body snatchers (1978)
results.creator_credit: Robert H Solo, Solofilm Productions and Philip Kaufman
results.brief_description: This remake of the 1956 classic takes place in the 1970s in San Francisco. Spores rain forth, unseen, from outer space, and soon strange flowers begin to bloom all over the city. One by one residents are suddenly losing thir individuality and becoming drone-like shadows of their former selves. As the phenomenon spreads, two Department of Health workers uncover the horrifying truth: that mysterious pods are cloning humans and destroying the originals. Cast includes: Donald Sutherland, Brooke Adams, Leonard Nimoy, Veronica Cartwright and Jeff Goldblum.

results.title: Invasion of the Body Snatchers
results.creator_credit: Walter Wanger, Allied Artists Pictures and Don Siegel
results.brief_description: Tense and atmospheric tale of alien duplicates who gradually hatch from pods and take over the inhabitants of a small town. Based on the novel by Jack Finney. Stars Kevin McCarthy and Dana Wynter.

results.title: Invaders from mars
results.creator_credit: Edward Alperson, National Pictures and William Cameron Menzies
results.brief_description: After witnessing the landing of a flying saucer, a young boy finds his parents changed and alien in their behaviour. This film’s cult status is based on the art direction by director-designer Menzies who designed the sets to enhance events as seen through the boy’s eyes. A long expository dialogue-bound scene and the producer’s insistence on inserting stock footage of army manoeuvres weakened Menzies’ concept. This is the full-length version with the original ending that was cut from the version previously released in Australia. Menzies’ film was the first of the alien invaders genre to be made in colour. It was originally intended to be a 3-D release but the idea was dropped before production began.

results.title: Intrusive igneous rocks
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 14 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Unveils the rock-forming processing of magmas that do not reach earth’s surface but solidfy. Igneous rocks are classed as plutonic and volcanic; the differences are determined by the way the magma cools and hardens. Not all minerals are formed at the same time, and the crystalisation process results in different minerals being formed. Igneous activity is related also to Plate tectonics, while the moon is largely made up of igneous material rarely found on the surface of the earth.

results.title: Introduction to Yoga
results.brief_description: In this video, especially made for beginners, Laliita Gilbert shows us: breathing, standing exercises, relaxation techniques. This highly instructive video introduces the viewer to the benefits of the essential philosophy and preparatory techniques of yoga.

results.title: Introduction to work sampling
results.creator_credit: University of California, Los Angeles and Oscar Patterson
results.brief_description: Points out that single or unsystematical observations may give quite erroneous ideas of how efficiently a worker is employed. Explains the “random” concept in statistics, using a bowl of 10,000 marbles of two colors. Applies the random sample method to a model of a machinist’s working day. Presents the claim that work sampling can provide many results of stop-watch time-and-motion study: standard hours of production work; average performance index; indication of idle time and delay causes.

results.title: Introduction to video
results.creator_credit: John A. Givins, Lynn John and KTV Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Video tech”.
This introductory episode provides a basic outline of the various formats, how videotapes actually work, different sorts of video cameras - betacam, professional cams, consumer cams, the camcorder, and how to get good sound on the videotape.

results.title: Introduction to the performing arts: opera with Henry Butler
results.creator_credit: Robert Saudek, Robert Saudek Associates, Learning Corporation of America and Roger Englander
results.brief_description: Henry Butler, stage director for the New York Metropolitan Opera Company, comments on the emotional inspiration for opera, famous opera houses, and trends in opera today. Includes interviews with the performers, and long extracts from performances of La Traviata and I Pagliacci.
